facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 32 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 32 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 25, 1957 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 992 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 25, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 992 of 1954,

facts.text: Arising out of the judgment and order dated January 25, 1954 of the Additional Sessions Judge, Gorakhpur in Sessions Trial No. 71 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 25, 1954, of the Additional Sessions Judge, Gorakhpur in Sessions Trial No. 71 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on September 3, 1959 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. September 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: The facts of the case as found by the High Court are no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case, as found by the High Court, are no longer in dispute and the question that is raised

facts.text: Gopal deceased was married to the sister of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal deceased was married to the sister of the appellant. The appellant and his father Badri were living

facts.text: The appellant and his father Badri were living in a railway quarter at Gorakhpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his father Badri were living in a railway quarter at Gorakhpur. Gopals sister was married

facts.text: Gopal's sister was married to one Banarsi who was living in another railway quarter nearby.

anchor.surface_text: Gopals sister was married to one Banarsi, who was also living in another railway quarter nearby. Gopal had been

facts.text: Gopal had been living for some time with his father-in-law but shifted to Banarsi's house due to strained relations.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal had been living for some time with his father-in-law. They did no, however, pull on well together and Gopal shifted to the house of Banarsi.

facts.text: Gopal shifted again to Banarsi's quarter about 15 days before the occurrence on June 11, 1953 at about 10 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Badri persuaded Gopal to come back to his house but the relations remained strained and eventually Gopal shifted again to the quarter of Banarsi about 15 days before the present occurrence which took place on June 11, 1953,

facts.text: Gopal's wife continued to live with her father as she was unwilling to go with Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: Gopals wife had continued to live with her father as she was unwilling to go with Gopal. Her father Badri and her brother Vishwanath appellant

facts.text: Badri and appellant sided with the wife and refused to let her go with Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: Her father Badri and her brother Vishwanath appellant sided with her and refused to let her go with Gopal.

facts.text: Gopal suspected his wife was carrying on with one Moti who visited Badri's quarter.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal also suspected that she had been carrying on with one Moti who used to visit Badris quarter.

facts.text: Gopal had got a job in the local department some months before the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, Gopal was keen to take away his wife, the more so as he had got a job in the local department some months before and wanted to lead an independent life.

facts.text: On June 11, 1953 there was a quarrel between the appellant and Gopal about the girl but nothing untoward happened.

anchor.surface_text: On June 11, there was some quarrel between the appellant and Gopal about the girl but nothing untoward happened then and the appellant went back to his quarter

facts.text: Gopal asked Banarsi's sons to help bring back his wife; Banarsi arrived and all four went to Badri's quarter.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal asked Banarsis sons to help him in bringing back his wife. Banarsi also arrived and then all four of them went to Badris quarter to bring back the girl.

facts.text: Banarsi and his two sons stood outside while Gopal went inside Badri's quarter.

anchor.surface_text: On reaching the place, Banarsi and his two sons stood outside while Gopal went in.

facts.text: Badri came out and refused Banarsi's request to let the girl go with Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, Badri came out and was asked by Banarsi to let the girl go with her husband. Badri was not agreeable to it and asked Banarsi not to interfere in other peoples affairs.

facts.text: Gopal came out dragging his reluctant wife; she caught hold of the door and a tug-of-war followed.

anchor.surface_text: While Badri and Banarsi were talking, Gopal came out of the quarter dragging his reluctant wife behind him. The girl caught hold of the door as she was being taken out and a tug-of-war followed between her and Gopal.

facts.text: Appellant shouted to his father that Gopal was adamant.

anchor.surface_text: -The appellant was also there and shouted to his father that Gopal was adamant.

facts.text: Badri replied that if Gopal was adamant he should be beaten tomaro.

anchor.surface_text: Badri, thereupon replied that if Gopal was adamant he should be beaten tomaro .

facts.text: Appellant took out a knife from his pocket and stabbed Gopal once; the knife penetrated into the heart.

anchor.surface_text: On this the appellant took out a knife from his pocket and stabbed Gopal once. The knife penetrated into the heart and Gopal fell down senseless.

facts.text: Gopal fell senseless; steps taken to revive him failed; he was taken to hospital but died by the time they reached.

anchor.surface_text: Steps were taken to revive Gopal but without success. Thereupon, Gopal was taken to the hospital by Badri and the appellant and Banarsi and his sons and some others, but Gopal died by the time they reached the hospital.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Badri of abetment as he could not have realised appellant would stab Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Sessions Judge was of opinion that Badri who had merely asked the appellant to beat Gopal could not have realised that the appellant would take out a knife from his pocket and stab Gopal. Badri was, therefore, acquitted of abetment.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted appellant holding right of private defence extended to causing death but no more harm than necessary caused.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge was further of opinion that the appellant had the right of private defence of person, and that this right extended even to the causing of death as it arose on account of an assault on his sister which was with intent to abduct her. He was further of opinion that more harm than the circumstances of the case required was not caused and therefore the appellant was also acquitted.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court against acquittal of both accused.

anchor.surface_text: The State then appealed to the High Court against the acquittal of both accused.

facts.text: High Court upheld acquittal of Badri but set aside acquittal of appellant, convicted under s. 304 Part II and sentenced to 3 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the acquittal of Badri. The acquittal of - the appellant was set aside on the ground that the case was not covered by the fifth clause of s. 100 and the right of -private defence of person in this case did not extend to the voluntary causing of death to the assailant and therefore it was exceeded. ... The appellant was therefore convicted under s. 304, Part 11, of the Penal Code and sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 25, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 992 of 1954,
convicted under s. 304, Part 11, of the Penal Code and sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment.

concepts.unlisted_description: When right of private defence of body extends to voluntary causing of death.

anchor.surface_text: Section 100 with which we are concerned is in these terms- The right of private defence of the body extends, under the restrictions mentioned in the last preceding section, to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the assailant, if the offence which occasions the exercise of the right be of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated, namely- First-Such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that death will otherwise be the consequence of such assault Secondly-Such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that grievous hurt will otherwise be the consequence of such assault Thirdly-An assault with the intention of committing rape Fourthly-An assault with the intention of gratifying unnatural lust Fifthly-An assault with the intention of kidnapping or. abducting Sixthly-An assault with the intention of wrongfully confining a person under circumstances which may reasonably cause him to apprehend that he will be unable to have recourse to the public authorities for his release.

concepts.interpretation: Each clause requires an assault (offence under s.352); intention words like 'abducting' need not themselves be punishable offences.

concepts.unlisted_description: When right of private defence of body extends to voluntary causing of death.

anchor.surface_text: Section 99 lays down that the right of private defence in no case extends to the inflicting of more harm than it is necessary to inflict for the purpose of defence.

concepts.interpretation: Appellant did not exceed as only one knife blow given, not more harm than necessary despite fatal outcome.

anchor.surface_text: the question that is raised in this appeal is whether the appellant had exceeded the right of private defence of person.

issues.text: whether the decision in Ram Saiyas case is correct

anchor.surface_text: The main question therefore that falls for consideration in this appeal is whether the decision in Ram Saiyas case 1 is correct.

arguments.claim: Badri who had merely asked the appellant to beat Gopal could not have realised that the appellant would take out a knife from his pocket and stab Gopal, hence acquitted of abetment.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Sessions Judge was of opinion that Badri who had merely asked the appellant to beat Gopal could not have realised that the appellant would take out a knife from his pocket and stab Gopal. Badri was, therefore, acquitted of abetment.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court upheld the acquittal of Badri.

arguments.claim: The appellant had the right of private defence of person extending even to the causing of death as it arose on account of an assault on his sister with intent to abduct her, and more harm than the circumstances required was not caused, hence acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge was further of opinion that the appellant had the right of private defence of person, and that this right extended even to the causing of death as it arose on account of an assault on his sister which was with intent to abduct her. He was further of opinion that more harm than the circumstances of the case required was not caused and therefore the appellant was also acquitted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees that right extended to death and no excess harm under s.99.

arguments.claim: The case was not covered by the fifth clause of s.100 and the right of private defence of person did not extend to the voluntary causing of death to the assailant, hence exceeded and conviction under s.304 Part II.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the acquittal of Badri. The acquittal of - the appellant was set aside on the ground that the case was not covered by the fifth clause of s. 100 and the right of -private defence of person in this case did not extend to the voluntary causing of death to the assailant and therefore it was exceeded. The High Court relied on an earlier decision of its own in Emperor v. Ram Saiya  1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated, namely- First-Such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that death will otherwise be the co

arguments.court_reasoning: View in Ram Saiya incorrect; plain meaning of 'abducting' is as per s.362 definition, not requiring punishable offence.

arguments.claim: The word 'abducting' in the fifth clause of s.100 refers to abduction as defined in s.362, not only punishable forms; assault with intention of abducting by force extends right to causing death; Ram Saiya view incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: the view taken in Ram Saiyas case  1  is that the word abducting used in the fifth clause of s. 100 of the Penal Code refers to such abducting as is an offence under that Code and not merely to the act of abduction as defined in s. 362 thereof. Mere abduction is not an offence... We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case  1  is not correct and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning.

arguments.claim: When the appellant's sister was being abducted by force, there was an assault on her with intention of abducting, so right of private defence of her body extended to causing death.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being compelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death.

arguments.claim: The right of private defence never extends to inflicting more harm than necessary, and appellant inflicted more harm than necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the appellant was within the restrictions prescribed by s. 99. It was urged that the right of private defence never extends to the inflicting of more harm than what is necessary for the purpose of defending and that in this case the appellant inflicted more harm than was necessary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he takes steps to defend himself, even to the extent of causing death of the person abducting. The framers of the Code knew that abduction by itself w

arguments.court_reasoning: Only one blow with knife given, which unfortunately was fatal, but not more harm than necessary; cited Amjad Khan.

arguments.claim: Appellant was within restrictions of s.99 as he inflicted no more harm than necessary; only one knife blow given.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this is not so. The appellant gave only one blow with a knife which he happened to have in his pocket. It is unfortunate that the blow landed right into the heart and therefore Gopal died. But considering that the appellant had given only one blow with an ordinary knife which, if it had been a little this way or that, could not have been fatal, it cannot be said that he inflicted more harm than was necessary for the purpose of defence.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case 1 is not correct and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case 1 is not correct and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of s.100 fifth clause requires only assault with intent to abduct as per s.362 definition (force or deceit); no need for further punishable intent under ss.364-369; defender need not assess abductor's further intentions; framers omitted qualification; distinguishes/overrules Ram Saiya which limited to punishable abduction.

holdings.text: when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being compelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being compelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show Gopal dragged reluctant wife by force from father's place (tug-of-war at door), constituting assault (s.352) with intent to abduct by force (s.362); applies s.100 fifth clause (per h1) extending right to death; s.97 provides basic right of defence of person.

holdings.text: The appellant gave only one blow with a knife which he happened to have in his pocket. [...] it cannot be said that he inflicted more harm than was necessary for the purpose of defence.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this is not so. The appellant gave only one blow with a knife which he happened to have in his pocket. It is unfortunate that the blow landed right into the heart and therefore Gopal died. But considering that the appellant had given only one blow with an ordinary knife which, if it had been a little this way or that, could not have been fatal, it cannot be said that he inflicted more harm than was necessary for the purpose of defence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only single stab with ordinary knife, fortuitously fatal (heart penetration); not excessive given circumstances of ongoing forceful abduction; analogous to Amjad Khan case; harm not more than necessary under s.99.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case 1 is number companyrect and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning. Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being companypelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death. The next question is whether the appellant was within the restrictions prescribed by s. 99.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court view in Ram Saiya's case held incorrect; appellant had right of private defence of person extending to causing death; no more harm than necessary inflicted

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being compelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death.

We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case 1 is number companyrect and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning. Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being companypelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death. The next question is whether the appellant was within the restrictions prescribed by s. 99.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this is not so. The appellant gave only one blow with a knife which he happened to have in his pocket. It is unfortunate that the blow landed right into the heart and therefore Gopal died. But considering that the appellant had given only one blow with an ordinary knife which, if it had been a little this way or that, could not have been fatal, it cannot be said that he inflicted more harm than was necessary for the purpose of defence.

We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in Ram Saiyas case 1 is number companyrect and the fifth clause must be given full effect according to its plain meaning. Therefore, when the appellants sister was being abducted, even though by her husband, and there was an assault on her and she was being companypelled by force to go away from her fathers place, the appellant would have the right of private defence of the body of his sister against an assault with the intention of abducting her by force and that right would extend to the causing of death. The next question is whether the appellant was within the restrictions prescribed by s. 99.
